titleInfo.title: Control Techniques to Increase Power Density for MMC Medium Voltage Grid-Tie Converter

name.namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.abstract: In today's world, power electronic converters are used in numerous applications. The size and weight of these converters are important factors that affect their power density. The converters that convert direct current (DC) to alternative current (AC) have advanced from two level voltage source converters to multilevel converters to achieve a higher power density. The multilevel converters have a higher power density and are suitable for various applications. A modular multilevel converter (MMC) is one of the most popular multilevel converters due to its modular nature and scalability. The focus of this research is on the control methods to increase power density in Modular Multilevel Converters. The advanced state of the art control methods used to reduce size of components like inductors and capacitors are presented. Then, Y-Matrix modulation is discussed as a modulation that enables MMC's self-voltage balancing. As a result of this modulation, the power density can be improved for MMC by eliminating the arms' inductors and converting it into Switched capacitor MMC(SC-MMC). This SC-MMC can balance capacitors voltage in each switch cycle. A mathematical discussion of Y-Matrix generation is presented in this research, both for SC-MMC without a middle submodule and for SC-MMC equipped with a middle submodule. A practical implementation of Y-Matrix modulation is then presented, followed by an experimental validation. The size of the capacitors in MMC is another barrier to power density. This research analyzes low-order harmonic power oscillation of MMC submodules. Low-order harmonic power oscillations cause MMC submodule capacitors to encounter large voltage ripples. Consequently, large capacitors are required, resulting in low- power density for MMCs. A theoretical analysis of fundamental frequency voltage ripple elimination in MMC's capacitors is presented in this paper. A controller is designed based on this analysis and capacitors are sized for this condition. This method shows significant capacitor reduction in MMC.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
GRID-TIE CONVERTER, Modular Multilevel Converter, Power Electronics
Fang Z. Peng, Professor Directing Dissertation; Juan C. Ordonez, University Representative; Hui "Helen" Li, Committee Member; Jinyeong Moon, Committee Member.
